Let's reverse the roles here.

Imagine that you are the younger brother and you finally manage to get with your older brother's hot female friend. After you've been together for a while, it comes to light that your partner is only with you because your older brother wasn't interested. That would be crushing and humiliating.

Now let's imagine that you are the older brother. You aren't interested in this female friend of yours, but your younger brother is smitten. You drag these two people to outings together so your younger brother has the chance to get to know her, in the hopes of sparks lighting up. Then the female friend confesses that she's interested in you. You have two options: Be a massive whore, break your brother's heart, and date the girl you KNOW he's crushing on. Or reject her politely, in solidarity with your bro.

No matter what you choose, you're gonna make a horrible mistake. Just abandon all hope of dating the older sister, and don't lead the younger sister on.

If you're not actually all that SET on the older sister and you've just got a minor crush on her, and you genuinely like the younger sister as a person, and see her as dateable, go for the younger sister. It's scummy to date the 'second-best' sister if you think poorly of her, and you consider her older sister to be way better, but it's not scummy if you genuinely respect and like them both, and find them both attractive. You know... as long as you haven't got some kind of oneitis for the older sister.

Being introverted or extroverted has nothing to do with your level of social skills, nor with your desire to be social.

The difference is simple. At a social event, generally speaking an extrovert will become more energized by all the social interaction and an introvert will require some alone time afterwards to reflect and recharge by themselves.

I’m 20 and have been this way since I was about 13 and middle school kicked in.

I’m an outcast, a loner, etc, and I know that I’m wasting my life being alone and a part of me is jealous of others and feels FOMO, but I’m also proud to be a loner. Maybe I’m arrogant, but I look at people my age in the rat race of always trying to one-up each other, the constant use of social media, getting into petty drama that doesn’t matter and then I look at myself. Takes great care of myself, finds pleasure in going for walks and watching the sun set, working on my own comic series, I can’t help but think that I’m better for it?

Yeah, my life is pretty bleak in that I’m coming home from work to the same dark room everyday and I’m missing out on a social life, but I honestly tried to befriend others and I just can’t do it. I’ve never had any friends, I’ve always been too weird to fit in with the normies, and too normie for the weirdos. I’m too scared for suicide, but the small things like listen for music and walking around make me happy and I get a sense of pride, even if misplaced, in that I’m just doing as I please and I’m better for it, I’m my own best friend. Trying to fit in or dress nicer feels like admitting defeat, like yeah I’m putting on this shirt because I want other people to think I look nice and pry for their validation, I’m not doing that, I respect myself. It’s not even like I’m a dick, I’m pretty easygoing and polite if not nearly serious enough.

But then again, I know that my life is pathetic and empty through the lens of anyone that isn’t me and I’ve repressed it over the years, but I do desire some form of social life and to be apart of something.

The hell do I do?

The art of Computer Programming is not for beginners and I think it's getting dated at this point (it started being written in the 60s but it is not finished yet) but it might be worth a read
It depends on what you want to do
>algorithms
Pick one of Kleinberg-Tardos, CLRS and Dasgupta Papadimitriou Vagirani depnding on which style do you prefer and use the other two as supplementary. I recomend Kleinberg-Tardos
>theory of computation
Sipser or Papadimitriou
>computer architecture
Patterson Hennesy (the beginner book, if you want, continue with the advanced book)
There are more topics that might interest you
>operating systems
>computer networks
>programing languages
>compilers
>cryptohraphy
>data bases
>artificial intelligence
>machine learning
>software engineering
>human computer interaction
>...

>>28218605
Listen, no one does anything because they should. No one does anything they don’t want to, unless they HAVE to, ie. can’t live any other way. It’s not good or bad to “work hard”. The reason you don’t do them, is because something in you knows it wouldn’t change anything. Because it is done from the stand point that you are not good enough. And that is a thirst that can never be quenched. The parts of yourself that you’re fighting are at least as intelligent and wise (probably more) than the parts you identify with. It is your subconscious, and it has been trying to teach you life changing lessons your entire life. Things you could have known decades ago, that you didn’t want to know, because you think you are worthless, and a useless creature that must be brute forced into a certain appearance. And you are telling me you don’t understand why you’re not doing that? You don’t want to. NO ONE would want to, unless they had no choice. All this self-improvement bullshit culture is a farce. It is for the sort of hard-earned, insignificant improvements others around you can’t even see.

The truth is that no one ever changes, unless it’s easy. And it’s easy when you whole-heartedly want it, or you absolutely have no choice. It’s never about struggling to get yourself to do it. That’s just self-rejection. That is the result of identifying with your conditioning, the internalized voice of your parents and society. That isn’t you, and therefore it isn’t what YOU want.

posts.com:
Genuine love takes at least 12 months (usually longer) to develop.

I think she may just be inexperienced. A metric fuck ton of people mistake infatuation for love, those bubbly butterfly feelings that form the initial honeymoon phase. I'd ask her what she means when she says she loves you and if it's confirmed to be infatuation (which is reasonable to start forming after a second date) then this could form a teachable moment.

It doesn't necessarily mean she's crazy. If it's confirmed to be just her misunderstanding what love is then it's worth a third date to see what's going on.

>>28212991
My very close friend is legally blind, she has very low vision. She has a hard time dating because people do make assumptions on her disability and can be reactive/upset about being told what is and is not ok. Direct communication is best, asking about boundaries and her thoughts/opinions on things. I know something that makes my friend uncomfortable is when people try to “help” her unsolicited, like grabbing her arm to walk her across the street. She can’t see them or feel she has mobile control to stop them, so it’s scary. Another thing is general micro aggressions/misinformation people have of blindness, so it’s best to communicate, be patient when corrected, and keep awareness about you.

posts.com: How do I find the motivation and tenacity to commit to a task? I can't even do things that I really want to do, like play video games or jerk off.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28219386
Two things.

First, on tasks you care about, make a list of steps that would complete the task and make them as small as makes reasonable sense.

>Clean my trash heap of a room
Is demoralizing, hard, and intimidating, a step list like
>pick up all tissues on the floor and put them into a trashbag
>gather all clothing into the laundry basket
>take the sheets off of the bed and put them into the washing machine

Makes it not so big because you know what to do and can point at progress along the way.

Second, make sure you're taking care of yourself by getting enough sleep. It's between 11-1PM in the US. If this post isn't doubles, start winding down, turn your computer off, and start prepping for bed over the next hour. Get some good sleep so you're refreshed for tomorrow.

As for my parents, I can say that I have an ok relationship with them, I am a very reserved person with them and sometimes use vulgar language but overall everything is in order. I never laid a hand on anyone and I really hate violence. Although looking at it this way, my social introversion and weirdness made some people dislike me and in response they saw me as an easy target. They would fight me, hit me, drag me through the halls, call me the worst. That lowered my self-esteem. As for friendships in general, I had a childhood best friend who disappeared from my life in one fell swoop and a few friends who were more or less as socially retarded as I was but with whom I could sometimes feel relaxed. >If I'm mildly autistic (weird speech mannerisms, clumsy body language/motor skills) how much does my potential dating pool shrink because of this?
You need to get rid of this shit pronto. Humans are irrational creatures. They make decisions about whether or not they like you based on factors that aren't strictly logical. People don't decide whether they like you based on how good a person you are or the number in your bank account. It's all about how you make them feel when you're with them.

Strange mannerisms and clumsy body language mark you as a defective, and this will make people want to reject you on a deep, atavistic level. Their lizard brain goes, this is not someone I want in my tribe, this is definitely not someone I want to breed with. You'll be rejected no matter how good your other qualities are.

You need to work on making your mannerisms and bodily movements as "normal" as possible (without seeming like you're trying too hard). If your voice is weird, you might consider visiting a speech therapist. These small things make a big difference. They're crucial.

posts.com:
>>28220148
Totally. Nausea, headaches, stomach cramps/diarrhea et cetera are very often stress related. Pressure on your chest is also a classic one.

I know if you are so stressed you might not have the time or mental space for it, but look into meditation if you want to learn how to deal with stress better. What also helps is forcing yourself to slow down. When you get stressed you start showing physical symptoms like doing things faster (breathing, walking, talking, eating) or stress tics like tapping fingers or feet fast. If you catch yourself doing that and then you force yourself to breathe more slowly, move more slowly, talk more slowly, it'll help a bit. The thing is that you get into a feedback loop otherwise: you start breathing faster because you are stressed, but your fast breathing also continuously reaffirms to your brain that you are in stress mode, on high alert.

I think being a gentleman had its time and place back when treating women with indifference and/or ridicule was much more widely accepted.

Nowadays when I think of a modern gentleman I guess I would think of a man who is courteous - someone who notices when someone else gets cut off and finds a way to help them finish what they wanted to say, someone who is aware of his surroundings and finds it important to go about his business without doing so at the expense of others, someone who holds it in high esteem to benefit others with his presence.
This is a wonderful, very attractive and also very useful quality to have, but it is not gendered.

I do not like classic gentlemanly acts like pulling the chair out for me, wanting to pay, walking in between me and the road, because in my experience men who find it important to do these things often have a pretty set idea of gender dynamics. I feel much more seen and respected when I feel treated like a person rather than treated like a woman.

>>28220312
My boyfriend and I made a mutual decision (it was his idea though) to take a break from each other for two months because we did not want to break up but we were so stuck in the relationship, the same kind of arguments kept popping up again and again, that we couldn't really think of what else to try to improve things.

This is my only experience, so I don't want to say that "it works", but for us it did. We were very much stuck in negative emotions about our relationship and each other and the two month break/radio silence forced us both to focus more on not wanting to lose the other person, missing the other one. We had also gotten super defensive through all the fighting and I think the distance helped to soften our attitudes again. And after the two months, I think it just relaxed a lot of tension in the relationship to feel that despite all the hard things, we still wanted to try for and with each other. It's almost a year ago now and our relationship has not been as bad or difficult as it was before the break in that time frame.

That said, a break imo really is a last resort before breaking up. I am also not sure if our break would've been as effective if we had not been ready to seriously contemplate the option of parting ways.

>>28219206
>Girls how many of you would be interesting in being in an MFF throuple?
I've done that. It was great. But in my experience roughly 99% of guys who think they would be into this actually aren't. They think about it in purely selfish terms - I get to fuck two girls, I get threesomes, I get live-action lesbian porn - but the reality is that your girlfriend has someone else in her life who is just as important to her as you are; you are are sharing her equally with someone else - all her time, her love, her sexuality. Plenty of times the two of them will be hanging out together and excluding you completely. That's a very different thing.

Basic logistics become more complex. It's often hard enough for *two* people to agree on where they want to go together, or what they want for dinner, or what colour to paint the spare bedroom. When absolutely everything has to be what *three* people agree on, everything takes longer to decide, and everything has more potential to lead to disagreements.

You've got to worry about three people all finding jobs within easy reach of each other.

You also get all kinds of problems with outside people failing to understand the nature of what's going on. Can you imagine trying to explain to your son's school "No, it'll be my *other* partner who picks him up today." Or people who have seen you with girl A, then see her and girl B together and assume that she's cheating on you with another woman. Trying to explain everything to all three families. It's not for the faint-hearted.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28220368
Granted, girls all have their own type and not just when it comes to looks or demeanor, we all have individual needs in a relationship. E.g. one girl might expect a boyfriend to make her life more exciting and fun (someone to travel with! a plus one to any boring event! someone who takes her to places she wouldn't even think of herself!) while another girl might experience way too much excitement in her life already and long for a partner who makes her feel relaxed, accepted, at home, who is a safe haven to retreat into.

So basically you will never reach a point where you can impress just any girl, you will always be incompatible with what some others are looking for.

But nobody looks more attractive than when they are enjoying their life. Seeing a guy laugh and joke with friendships that are obviously filled with warmth, seeing a guy's face light up when he talks about the hobby he loves to nerd about, or seeing him get all concentrated and focus trying to explain something he is passionate about the perfect way... Seeing someone who is relaxed, in a good mood, open and curious, that is always attractive. Basically try to focus less on what she might like and more on what you like and you will impress the right girls who are compatible with you.

In practice this means asking girls along to group events rather than always wanting to be one on one, and that it is a lot easier to meet and impress girls in an environment where you already thrive (like at a job or education you love and excel at, at hobby events, at a houseparty of a dear friend that you are happy to attend).

posts.sub: In this thread we are going to look for the cure for depression
posts.com:
I have no proof or medical studies to show that this is the case, but I also have no doubts. I believe that to get out of depression, tiredness, fatigue and all that shit, you first have to work your body, since a healthy body is a healthy mind, for that it is good to do sports, whatever it is. it is as long as it keeps our body busy. Another important factor is studying, it doesn't really matter what, it doesn't matter if it's for university, school or for yourself, you have to do it to keep your mind occupied with something productive. I would also say that looking for a job, or generating income with a startup, as this will keep our mind and body busy, while giving us money, in itself gives us a reason to keep going, especially when you are working on something of your own.

Another important point is to stop comparing yourself to others, stop thinking that the other is better than you because you have more knowledge, money or physical condition. It is also very silly to think about issues such as superiority or inferiority, we are all human, we all have problems and difficulties in life, of course there are degrees of this, but this does not have to be a limitation. You have to focus on yourself, on your problems, on your virtues, on your life, and not on that of others.

Another issue is guilt and remorse, which depending on the person can be the easiest part, or difficult to overcome, because it is easy to forgive others, but sometimes it is difficult, if not impossible, to forgive yourself. No matter how dirty your hands are, they can always be cleaned. You have to accept your sins, accept what you did wrong and live with it. Go to a priest, a psychologist, or tell someone you trust what you did, this can help, it doesn't matter if you think psychology is a joke, or if you don't believe in God, the important thing is to somehow get the weight off What are you wearing.

posts.com: think you need to begin with the question of why do people in general feel emotions to begin to answer why someone would fall into a perpetual negative emotional state. Emotions are clearly intrinsic instincts not learned although learned experiences can change what triggers the emotions to occur. These instincts evolved over time to prod people towards the actions that have proven to be evolutionarily successful over time. Because people are highly social animals and there is fierce competition between different social groups of people, many of the emotions we feel are actually designed to not simply benefit yourself and improve your own survival, but to benefit the survival of the entire social group. These instincts go hand in hand with developed cultural mores.

It all comes down to conditioning or lack thereof

The other aspect is metaphysical, why do it if it has no meaning?
You have to build up a cohesive worldview that encompasses purpose and reason in order to get things done

>>28211626
I can't recommend it highly enough.
Waiting a little bit helps only a little bit, because a few months in the grand scheme of things is very little.
Lurk this board for a while and you'll see some thread of a guy who wants to break up with a long-term gf he's been stringing along for *years* (or trashes an ex), includes a list of pros and cons, and 9 times out of 10, at the top of the "pros" list, he puts 'sex is nice'. Many guys are content to stay in a dead-end relationship just because it's convenient, and they'll happily take up most of a woman's youth if they're allowed to. This is something you'd never be able to prevent if you only wait for a set period of time instead of expecting commitment.

Meanwhile, if you wait, you're basing the relationship entirely on how much you like each other as people. If you don't get along and he knows there's no way he'll get sex without committing (users are loathe to do that), he'll save you a lot of time and heartache and move on quickly himself. It might get demoralizing seeing guys bail on hearing it, but if you're dating to find a compatible partner, they are doing you a favor.
Waiting until marriage also selects exclusively for guys who put commitment before sex, rather than the other way around--and it gives you a way to test a guy's intentions, because the duplicitous ones will try to pressure you either for sex or some sexual "compromise" so he can still get himself off without commitment.

And there's nothing like the intimacy of knowing that you and your spouse have only been with each other. That's something you can only count on if you wait, and it's just sad that so many people convince themselves that this romantic ideal is unattainable today. There are plenty of very good reasons to wait besides the ones I've listed. Please don't miss out on the chance for something beautiful just because it seems odd or rare--it's doable and very worth it. Pic related. She's probably married by now.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28211377
>>28215203
Ideally, you want to engage in activities where you can spend time with a mix of people for longer than just bumping into a cute guy. Random strangers who look nice might as well be Tinder. It's a few-second cursory glance.

It can be someone you work with, you see occasionally at their job or at at your job, or just someone who you've seen a few times at the same establishment. Just a couple causal greetings with even a single sentence of observational chit chat can elevate a stranger to an acquaintance.
If you don't have those encounters, regularly get out more.

When you're with the guy you're interested in, the goal is to invite him to invite you. To broadcast that you're interested in being approached.
Dress well as appropriate, smile, look him in the eyes or at least the bridge of his nose between his eyes.
Inexperience, nervousness, laughter, stumbling, and awkwardness don't matter as much as you fear.

The idea is to facilitate him asking you with a core formula along the lines of complimenting him and mentioning something that he can ask you about leading to a date. Mentioning your favorite coffee place that he might like or a restaurant or place you'd like to go to sometime.

Being obvious but indirect is good and not the same thing as asking a guy out. He knows that you're interested but he still has to take the risk of asking. You don't seem desperate or easy.

You have to look at any job application from the employers perspective. What is it that YOU can bring to THEM? How does hiring YOU benefit THEM? And here's the clincher, how does the benefits YOU bring stack up against or compete with ALL THE OTHER CANDIDATES?

Btw, "they get an employee" is not an answer to that question. So you need to start at the absolute bottom in a shithole dead end job where they need employee scale but face high turnover so basically everyone who applies gets hired. That's where you need to focus your applications. Build up some work experience over 18 months and you'll be in a much better position to get employed somewhere else.

Remember, a paper qualification is meaningless in 2023 without experience.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28101153
A job change isn't going to fix your life. You need an entire lifestyle change. I'm 26 and went through something similar around 24. I'm going to recommend something cliche, but it fucking works for reasons I will elaborate on. Get in shape. If you are fat lose weight. If you are skinny hit the gym. Yes it's a physical thing but we are mostly after the mental benefits. When you improve physically it does several things mentally (arguably it has more mental benefits than physical). First is you learn to be disciplined. This obviously effects every aspect of life. You need discipline to escape NEETdom. Next it will give you a taste of that "better life". You will see hard effort turn into tangible rewards that you can be proud of. This can set off a chain reaction into other aspects of life you feel are lacking. Next is confidence. You will be more confident in your self and your abilities and it could be enough of a boost to get you to pounce on opportunities you otherwise would have missed by being passive. Perhaps most important of all it will get you out of the house and give you a hobby that isn't doing anything for you. This can lead to meeting new people and gives you a common interest hobby that you can share and engage with most people over. Don't forget other people will treat you better too.

All of that doesn't even take into account the physical aspects that also play a role in mental health. You would likely see an increase in certain hormones such as testosterone and a decrease in things like estrogen. These hormones play a huge role in mental health and having screwed up hormones probably play a huge role in depression and the like. In my opinion physical improvement is the number one best thing you can do if you are unhappy with your life because it lays the foundation for everything else. This is coming from someone who was fat basically my entire life and was well on my way to being an eternal neet. Getting /fit/ is what saved me.

>>28176244
I can't read it. My specific situation will not really relate to you.

The TL;DR is that I am an /out/ist through and through and nothing is going to change that.

I was in the army before college. Biology degree. Wildly depressed, and medicated for it. In college I did an internship with a conservation agency and it was fun, but I did the "right thing" and after school I just kept pursuing my "career path." Nothing glamorous or financially enticing, mind you. At 27 I had a paradigm shift, some major life changes (sister offed herself and ended a toxic 6 year relationship) and I took some seasonal /out/ work in Alaska to try and clear my heart and my head. Quit taking Zoloft during this time.

Following this, I left and did a "normal" job for about 1.25 years before I again felt the urge to get the fuck back outside. I worked for an environmental compliance contractor. I had a moment of clarity when a guy who had been there for 12 years told me he had a zoology degree. It made me sad to know he once shared my dreams. So I had to leave. Almost every person I knew told me that, at ~28 it was too late for a "career change" and I should just stay in place and effectively work at the same place until I died. I've since worked for a few different agencies/places for the feds doing /out/ things. I do not make much money. My job security is tenuous. But I feel at peace and wouldn't change it.

The point of my story is simply that if you recognize something you are truly passionate about, you should just stick with it, because trying to convince yourself you are happier in some other capacity just results in you being miserable. I wouldn't do something just to feel like you're moving forward, if that makes sense. I wouldn't do something you aren't "super passionate" about. Do not go be a cop simply because it is SOMETHING. Its your life, anon. 1/4 of it is over. Do you want to waste another 1/2 doing something you don't even give a shit about?

Step two is employment, which mostly sucks. Some people will tell you about how they have a passion for making other people rich, but they're mostly just coping. The purpose of employment is to GET CASH FLOW so you can either exit employment or at least have the funds to cope with it and stay sane. You should find something you're good at that you can tolerate without burning out that MAXIMIZES cash flow and pursue that. Ideally it should pay you to learn skills that you can deploy outside of employment so you can exit employment sooner rather than later. Think of employment as a bridge from virgin neetdom to chad neetdom. Some examples of viable options are trades, sales, it, coding meme, internet marketing. You can get an entry-level job in most of these fields with little-to-no experience. Grind certs, lie, just do whatever you need to do. Then start accruing skills that you can use for freelancing, consulting, contracting, ect in order to exit employment. >>28218500
>>28218542
It's a common problem for us to not be able to actually gather enough data to know what another person is feeling towards us and sometimes what they are feeling at all, autists just don't pick up on all the cues. I struggled with living in my head regarding women and totally missing out on both opportunities as well as chasing dead ends. Unfortunately there is no clear cut solution for this, I autopilot to bluntness in a friendly, genuine manner. It's been described as "endearing" which I'm not sure how to feel about. But basically straight up asking if they are into dating, can I kiss them etc. I mean shit, when I asked my wife to marry me I just slid a beautiful box I had carved for her with a ring in it, didn't say a word and didn't discuss marriage with her at all.

>deeper connections
Speaking for myself and from my own research, it seems "neuro-divergent" folk don't really need the same level of connection with others. I do perfectly fine alone for really long periods of time, it's lead me to marry a very independent woman (shes a researcher) who also enjoys digging her head into whatever project shes on. There can be a lot of conflict finding a partner who is able to give you the right amount of engagement without needing so much out of you socially or emotionally.

>meeting people
When I was younger, I really had to force myself to join my circle of friends, to go out and actually do things, but there is value there for sure, it's nice to have people support you and also put you in your place. They really helped me extend my comfort zone. I literally spent highschool lunches hanging out with a teacher I was that inept. University spent smoking cigarettes alone between classes etc. I've always been way too terrified for the gym, instead I do a lot of hiking and volunteering with animals etc. which has brought many like minded people into my life.

>complementing appearance
I typically don't comment on peoples looks unless I know them really well. You may have to just learn a set of cues to the other person that triggers their desire to share, people feel good talking about themselves, facilitating that will make people feel good about you. I get striking up convos out of the blue is hard, but it's an important skill normal people somehow just do on the regular without overthinking it, clearly you are overthinking it (I do too).

Weather, traffic, job/work, current events, open ended "what brings you here" type questions are all pretty safe. If I saw someone wearing an ghibli shirt I'd have to be super non autsitic about them being cool. I say this because I had a total aspie girl run up to me in a mall and comment on my shirt and try to strike a convo, I'm married and hate malls and I get they were trying but I kind of "kthanks" it and ruined their day, feel bad.

posts.com:
This sounds like a big communication/expectation/compatibility issue.
It's certainly normal for SOME people to sleep around before having an official conversation about exclusivity, but that tends to be the case among certain 'types.'

I think it's normal for you to feel weird about it. You've basically been made to realise you two have been on wildly different pages. Even if it was an innocent communication issue, that leaves you with massive uncertainty that undermines your ability to trust this person - trust that you're now truly exclusive, trust that not being exclusive prior doesn't undermine her feelings for you, trust that there are no other huge communication gaps that have been overlooked waiting to be revealed.
Also, maybe you're giving us the short version, but it rubs me the wrong way that she seems dismissive of your feelings by just saying it's normal. Even if she did nothing wrong, she should be sensitive to how you feel about it.

As someone who expects sexual exclusivity from the outset, I'd also have expected to know this information before we made our relationship official, because it's an important factor in my decision to become official to begin with. So the fact that you're seemingly just finding out is suspect to me (and how did you find out? Did she tell you, or did you come across it on your own?).

>we didn't have sex until around a month into our relationship.
As in, you were in an official relationship for a month before you slept together? Or you were dating for a month before you slept together?
Essentially, did she sleep with other people during this month long period? Because if you considered the two of you to be 'in a relationship,' that comes with a reasonable implication of exclusivity. If she was sleeping with other people during that time, that's a big deal IMO, whether it's a communication issue or a fidelity one.

posts.name: Eun
posts.com:
>How do you make friends when you're not sure if you're just really unlikeable?
have a benchmark on what a friend is and make an effort to have "aquaintances".

the idea is that a number acquaintances can "fit" your standard; through time a few will fall off your standard or some prove your standard could be better, and this sets you up to re-evaluate the standard if it's too high or too low and to calibrate. this, however, does not set you up to act indifferently to the customs or traditions of your acquaintances.

In my experience, people that make incredible companions are those who are comfortable in solitude. They are at peace with themselves, and most likely place value in things far greater than the likes of self-image, status, or reputation.
